habitat-loss-details.supporting-evidence: Site clearance for temporary access road as documented in construction management plan CMP-2022-01

bng-details.earlier-date-reason: Pre-development baseline established on 30 January 2023 to align with site clearance that occurred immediately before the 30 January 2020 cut-off date. This provides the most accurate baseline reflecting the site condition immediately before significant habitat loss occurred.

bng-condition-exemption-reason.reason: The development site is less than 0.5 hectares and is for residential development of fewer than 10 units, therefore qualifying for the small sites exemption under regulation 15 of the Biodiversity Gain Requirements (England) Regulations 2024.

data.name: Full application with biodiversity net gain details

habitat-loss-details.supporting-evidence: Evidence provided in ecological survey report ECO-2024-123

bng-details.irreplaceable-habitats-details: Ancient woodland present in north-east corner of site, covering 0.3 hectares

Ancient woodland present in north-western corner of site comprising approximately 0.8 hectares of mixed deciduous woodland with oak, ash and hazel. Woodland referenced in Natural England's Ancient Woodland Inventory as AW-REF-12345. No direct impacts to ancient woodland proposed - minimum 15m buffer zone maintained as per Standing Advice.

community-consultation.description: Held public meeting on 15th June 2025 at the village hall. Presented plans to 25 attendees and collected written feedback. Also distributed information leaflets to all properties within 100m of the site.
Consulted with local residents through door-to-door visits and posted notices in the community center. Received feedback from 15 households regarding the proposed extension.

con-remove-vary.reason: Condition 2 requiring natural stone cladding is no longer feasible due to cost and supply issues. Alternative materials would achieve the same visual effect.
con-remove-vary.condition-change: Replace condition 2 requiring natural stone with: 'The external walls shall be clad in high-quality reconstituted stone or approved equivalent material to match the existing building appearance, subject to sample approval by the Local Planning Authority.'

con-remove-vary.reason: The original condition requiring submission of a landscaping scheme within 3 months is no longer practical due to seasonal planting requirements. We request variation to allow submission within 6 months to ensure appropriate planting season.
The approved hours of operation condition is too restrictive for the business needs and does not align with similar businesses in the area.
con-remove-vary.condition-change: Amend condition 4 to read: 'The premises shall only operate between the hours of 07:00 and 22:00 Monday to Saturday and 09:00 and 18:00 on Sundays and public holidays' instead of the current 08:00 to 18:00 restriction.

data.name: Full application with conflict of interest declaration

conflict-of-interest.conflict-details: Jane Smith (applicant) is related to Planning Officer John Smith (brother) at the Local Planning Authority

data.name: Householder application with no conflict of interest

demolition-reason.reason: The existing structure is structurally unsound and poses a safety risk. The building cannot be economically renovated to meet current building standards and accessibility requirements.

demolition.description: Complete demolition of the Grade II listed Victorian warehouse building at 123 Industrial Street. The building comprises a three-storey brick and timber construction with cast iron windows, covering approximately 2,400 square metres of floor area.
demolition.reason: The building has suffered extensive structural damage due to fire and subsequent water damage. A structural engineer's report confirms that the building is beyond economic repair and poses a significant safety hazard. The cost of restoration would exceed Â£2.5 million, which is not economically viable for the proposed redevelopment.

demolition.description: Demolition of the 1960s concrete extension to the rear of the Grade II listed Georgian townhouse. The extension was added without planning consent and is not in keeping with the architectural character of the original building.
demolition.reason: The concrete extension detracts from the historic character and architectural integrity of the Grade II listed building. Its removal will restore the original proportions and appearance of the Georgian facade and allow for a more sympathetic replacement extension using traditional materials.

existing-use-details.land-part: Fields to north and east of site (approximately 2.5 hectares)
Agricultural storage buildings to west of farmhouse

existing-use-details.use-details: Mixed retail and community hall with occasional events
Petrol filling station with convenience store and car wash facilities

existing-use-details.land-part: Storage buildings at rear of site

desc-proposed-works.proposed-works-details: General description of works only - specific measurements and materials to be confirmed subject to detailed design development.

Demolition of existing single storey conservatory and construction of new single storey rear extension. The new extension will provide enlarged kitchen/dining/family area with study nook. Features include flat roof with roof lights, aluminium sliding doors, and external walls finished in timber cladding with brick plinth.

Single storey rear extension to existing dwelling house. The extension will provide additional kitchen and dining space with bi-fold doors opening to rear garden. Construction will be brick and tile to match existing dwelling with matching window styles and materials.

Two storey rear extension to provide enlarged kitchen/dining area at ground floor and additional bedroom with en-suite at first floor. Extension will feature pitched roof with tiles to match existing, render external walls painted to match existing colour scheme, and UPVC windows and doors in white to match existing fenestration.

Proposed wrap-around extension comprising single storey rear extension and single storey side return extension. The extension will create open plan kitchen/dining/living space with large format sliding doors to rear garden. Materials will include brick to match existing dwelling, zinc standing seam roof, and powder coated aluminium windows and doors.

desc-work-impacts-risks.description: Single-storey garden room extension to rear of existing bungalow. Timber frame construction with large glazed doors opening onto garden patio area.
desc-work-impacts-risks.impact-on-amenity: Minimal impact on neighbouring amenity due to single-storey design and rear garden location. Extension positioned 2 metres from side boundary to maintain privacy. No loss of light anticipated to adjacent properties given modest scale and orientation.
desc-work-impacts-risks.air-traffic-defence-impacts: No air traffic or defence impacts anticipated due to single-storey nature of extension maintaining existing building height. No mitigation required.
desc-work-impacts-risks.protected-view-impact: No impact on protected views as extension maintains existing roofline and is located to rear of property, not visible from any designated viewpoints or conservation area street scene.

desc-work-impacts-risks.description: Proposed two-storey rear extension to existing dwelling to provide additional living space including enlarged kitchen and new bedroom above. Extension will match existing brick construction with slate roof tiles.
desc-work-impacts-risks.impact-on-amenity: The extension will result in some loss of light to the rear windows of neighbouring property at 42 High Street. Mitigation includes stepped design reducing height adjacent to boundary and use of roof lights rather than dormer windows to minimize visual impact. Privacy concerns addressed through obscured glazing on side elevation windows.
desc-work-impacts-risks.air-traffic-defence-impacts: The proposed height increase is below aviation obstacle thresholds and will not impact air traffic or defence installations. No mitigation required.
desc-work-impacts-risks.protected-view-impact: The development is not located within any protected view corridors and will not impact designated views. The extension is positioned to the rear and will not be visible from the street scene or any heritage assets.

desc-work-impacts-risks.description: Loft conversion with rear dormer window to create additional bedroom in existing Victorian terraced house. Installation of three roof lights to front elevation and enlarged dormer to rear.
desc-work-impacts-risks.impact-on-amenity: Rear dormer will overlook neighbouring gardens but impact mitigated through use of obscured glazing in lower panels and positioning windows at higher level. Front roof lights maintain existing roofline character. Noise during construction limited to standard working hours.
desc-work-impacts-risks.air-traffic-defence-impacts: Modest height increase of 0.9 metres does not trigger aviation consultation thresholds. No defence assets in vicinity. No mitigation measures required.
desc-work-impacts-risks.protected-view-impact: Property located within conservation area but dormer designed to match existing historic character. Front elevation roof lights are conservation-style with slim profiles that preserve the Victorian streetscape character.

desc-work-impacts-risks.description: Construction of three-storey residential tower block comprising 24 apartments with ground floor commercial units. Modern steel and glass construction with green roof and solar panels.
desc-work-impacts-risks.impact-on-amenity: Significant impacts identified on adjacent residential properties through overshadowing and loss of privacy. Mitigation includes 3-metre setback from boundaries, angled windows to reduce overlooking, and landscaped buffer zone with mature tree planting to screen views.
desc-work-impacts-risks.air-traffic-defence-impacts: The proposed 18.5m height requires consultation with Civil Aviation Authority as it exceeds local height thresholds. Defence estate consultation confirms no impact on radar installations. Mitigation includes aviation warning lights and obstruction marking as required by CAA.
desc-work-impacts-risks.protected-view-impact: The development falls within the St Paul's Cathedral protected view corridor (Assessment Point 2A.1). Visual impact assessment demonstrates the building will not breach the protected silhouette when viewed from Parliament Hill. Design modifications include stepped roof profile to minimize visual intrusion.

desc-work-impacts-risks.description: Conversion of existing industrial warehouse to residential apartments with new fourth floor addition. Retention of brick facades with new steel and glass top floor featuring roof terrace.
desc-work-impacts-risks.impact-on-amenity: Limited residential properties in immediate vicinity due to industrial location. Roof terrace design includes 1.8m high screening to prevent overlooking of adjacent commercial properties. Sound insulation measures included to minimize noise transmission from rooftop activities.
desc-work-impacts-risks.air-traffic-defence-impacts: Site located 2km from regional airport requiring consultation with airport safeguarding authority. Height assessment confirms no impact on aircraft approach paths. Aviation obstruction lighting not required due to distance from runway and existing urban context providing higher reference points.
desc-work-impacts-risks.protected-view-impact: Development visible from listed church tower viewing point 800m away. Heritage impact assessment demonstrates new fourth floor uses recessive materials and stepped-back design to minimize visual prominence. Historic building facades retained and enhanced preserving industrial heritage character.

dev-type.development-description: Exploration and appraisal drilling for shale gas including horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing operations
Initial exploratory drilling to assess gas reserves with minimal surface infrastructure
Full-scale production operations for conventional oil extraction including processing facilities and storage tanks

data.description-list: Landscaping details for discharge of Condition 5 (Landscaping Scheme) of planning permission 2023/67890. Submitted documents include: detailed planting plan showing species, sizes and locations; maintenance schedule for first 5 years; soil preparation specifications; irrigation system details where required.

Submission of detailed material specifications for external wall cladding as required by Condition 3 of planning permission ref: 2023/12345. Includes: 1) Full technical specifications for insulated render system, 2) Color samples and finish details, 3) Manufacturer's certificates and performance data, 4) Installation methodology statement.

Discharge of multiple conditions for planning permission 2023/11111: Condition 4 (Construction Management Plan) - traffic routing, working hours, dust suppression measures; Condition 7 (Drainage Strategy) - detailed surface water management system with calculations and maintenance regime; Condition 9 (Noise Mitigation) - acoustic barrier specifications and installation details.

data.employment-impact: Net gain of 12.5 FTE positions due to business expansion
New development creating 24 FTE positions in previously vacant site
Net loss of 14 FTE positions due to operational restructuring

data.equipment-plan: Drilling operations will utilize a truck-mounted drilling rig with maximum height of 32 meters. Primary equipment includes: 1) Drilling rig model DR-500 with hydraulic rotary drive, 2) Mud circulation system with 200-barrel capacity, 3) Blow-out preventer (BOP) stack rated to 5000 psi, 4) Diesel generator sets (2 x 500kW), 5) Water storage tanks (3 x 10,000 gallon capacity), 6) Site compound with welfare facilities and equipment storage.

Production facility equipment for gas extraction and processing. Equipment includes: 1) Wellhead assemblies with gas gathering manifold, 2) Gas processing unit (maximum height 15 meters) with separation and compression equipment, 3) Storage tanks for produced water (2 x 5,000 barrel capacity), 4) Electrical switchgear and control systems housed in containerized units, 5) Emergency flare stack (height 25 meters) with safety shutdown systems, 6) Site access roads and hardstanding areas, 7) Perimeter fencing and security equipment.

Seismic survey operations using non-invasive geophysical methods. Equipment specification: 1) Vibroseis trucks (4 units) with maximum operating height of 4.5 meters, 2) Recording equipment trailer with seismic data acquisition system, 3) Survey support vehicles including pickup trucks and utility vehicles, 4) Portable welfare units and temporary site offices, 5) Geophone arrays and connecting cables, 6) GPS positioning equipment for precise survey mapping. All operations conducted from existing roads and temporary access routes.

foul-sewage.drainage-system-details: No foul sewage produced during extraction activities. Existing mains sewer connection maintained for site facilities only.
Specialist treatment system for oil extraction waste water. Details of treatment process and discharge arrangements shown on drawing DRG-004.
Existing mains sewer connection shown on drawing DRG-001. Connection will be made via new manhole as indicated on site plan.
Combination system with package treatment plant for main building and cess pit for temporary facilities. Connection to existing drainage shown on drawing DRG-003.
New septic tank and soakaway system to be installed as shown on drawing DRG-002. No connection to existing drainage required.

data.use-lawful-reason: The agricultural building has been used for storage of farm equipment and feed for over 15 years as part of the working farm operation. The use falls outside the Use Classes Order as it constitutes agricultural use ancillary to the farming activities on the landholding. No planning permission was required as the use benefits from agricultural permitted development rights.

documents.name: Farm business registration with Rural Payments Agency

data.specified-use: Agricultural storage ancillary to farming operations

data.use-lawful-reason: The site has been used for industrial purposes (Class B2 general industrial) for over 35 years. The existing manufacturing use was established in 1987 and has operated continuously without any material change of use. The original industrial use predates the current planning system requirements and has acquired lawful status through the passage of time.

documents.name: Insurance records showing continuous industrial use

data.use-lawful-reason: The property has been in continuous residential use as a single dwelling house (Class C3) for over 20 years. The use commenced in 2002 when the building was converted from commercial premises under planning permission 02/1456/FUL. Council tax records confirm continuous residential occupation since 2003.

documents.name: Planning permission 02/1456/FUL for conversion to residential

data.use-lawful-reason: The existing commercial use (Class E retail shop) has been operating continuously for over 15 years since 2008. The premises have been used for retail purposes under the same ownership with no material changes to the use class. Planning permission was originally granted in 2007 under reference 07/2234/FUL.

The existing use is for a specialist vehicle recovery and storage facility which does not fall within any standard use class. This sui generis use has been operating under the same ownership for 12 years since 2011. The use was established following grant of planning permission 11/0789/FUL and subsequent variations, with no enforcement action taken.
data.specified-use: Vehicle recovery and storage facility with associated repairs

data.use-lawful-reason: The site has been vacant and unused for over 8 years following cessation of the previous office use in 2015. The last lawful use was as Class E office premises under planning permission 98/2341/FUL. Although currently vacant, the building retains its lawful use rights for office purposes and could be reoccupied without requiring new planning permission.

documents.name: Business rates exemption records showing vacancy

data.grounds-for-application: The installation of discrete accessibility features including a platform lift and accessible WC facilities represents the minimum intervention necessary to comply with Equality Act 2010 requirements while preserving the Grade II listed building's special character. The proposed platform lift utilizes an existing service stairwell and requires no structural alterations to historic fabric. The accessible facilities are located within a modern extension added in the 1990s which is not part of the listed designation. All alterations are fully reversible and designed to have minimal visual impact on the building's character and appearance.

documents.name: Access audit and Equality Act compliance assessment
Platform lift technical specifications and installation method
Detailed drawings showing relationship to historic fabric

data.grounds-for-application: The replacement of modern electrical installations within the Grade II* listed building using like-for-like routes and methods constitutes essential maintenance that does not affect the building's special architectural or historic interest. The existing electrical system was installed in the 1970s and is not original to the building. The proposed works follow established cable routes within later floor voids and wall cavities, avoiding all historic fabric and decorative elements. The work is necessary for health and safety compliance and building insurance requirements, and the methods proposed ensure no impact on the listed building's character.

documents.name: Electrical condition survey and safety assessment
Proposed electrical layout showing existing routes

data.grounds-for-application: The proposed works to the Grade II listed building constitute minor alterations to the internal layout that do not affect the character or appearance of the listed building. The works involve the removal of non-original partition walls installed in the 1980s and do not impact any historic fabric or features of architectural or historic interest. Under section 7 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, these works do not constitute 'works for the demolition of a listed building or for its alteration or extension in any manner which would affect its character as a building of special architectural or historic interest' and therefore do not require listed building consent.

The proposed repair and conservation of the Grade I listed building's historic roof structure using traditional materials and methods constitutes essential maintenance that preserves rather than alters the building's special character. The work involves the repair of failing timber elements using matching hardwood and traditional joinery techniques, and the replacement of damaged historic roof tiles with reclaimed materials of matching provenance. All work follows the principle of minimal intervention and maximum retention of historic fabric. As the work constitutes like-for-like repair and conservation using traditional methods and materials, it does not require listed building consent under established planning guidance.

documents.name: Structural engineer's assessment of roof condition
Photographic record of existing roof structure
Historic building contractor's qualifications and experience

data.grounds-for-application: The proposed installation of conservation-grade secondary glazing to the historic windows constitutes maintenance work that preserves the special character of the Grade I listed building. The secondary glazing system has been specifically designed to be completely reversible, with minimal fixings that do not penetrate the historic window frames. The work enhances the building's thermal performance while preserving its historic fabric and visual appearance. As the work does not alter or affect the character of the listed building, listed building consent is not required under current planning law and guidance.

documents.name: Technical specifications for reversible secondary glazing
Historic window survey and condition report
Visual impact assessment with before/after photomontages
Manufacturer's installation guidance for heritage applications

grounds-ldc.reason: The proposed extension to the existing dwelling falls within permitted development rights under Class A of the General Permitted Development Order and does not require planning permission.

The mixed use of the property has multiple grounds for lawfulness: the residential component has been established for over 4 years under the pre-2024 rules, while the commercial component is lawful under existing use provisions.

grounds-ldc.other-details: The development qualifies under the specific exemption for agricultural buildings converted prior to 1988 under the General Development Order provisions that were in effect at the time.
grounds-ldc.reason: The conversion of the agricultural barn to residential use was completed in 1987 under permitted development rights that were available at that time, making the current use lawful.
The use of the building as a mixed commercial and residential property is lawful as it was established with proper planning permission and has been maintained in accordance with the approved plans.
The residential use of the property has been continuous for over 4 years without any enforcement action being taken by the local planning authority.

grounds-proposed-use.specified-use: Mixed-use development with residential units above retail space
grounds-proposed-use.reason: The development represents a mixed-use scheme that does not fall neatly into a single use class, combining residential (C3) and retail (A1) uses in a single building. This mixed-use configuration is considered lawful under the flexible use provisions of the General Permitted Development Order for town center locations.

The property has been continuously used as office space under Class B1 for over 4 years without planning permission, establishing lawful use through the passage of time under Section 171B of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

grounds-proposed-use.specified-use: Data center with high-voltage electrical equipment and backup generators
grounds-proposed-use.reason: The proposed data center use constitutes a sui generis use due to the unique operational requirements including 24/7 operation, high electrical load, and specialized cooling systems. The use is considered lawful as it represents intensification of existing industrial use within the same use class parameters.

grounds-proposed-use.temporary-details: Temporary use as restaurant for summer season only (May to September) for a maximum period of 2 years. Operating hours limited to 11:00-22:00 daily. Full restoration to previous use at end of temporary period.
grounds-proposed-use.reason: Temporary change of use from retail (A1) to restaurant (A3) is considered lawful under permitted development rights for temporary uses up to 28 days per calendar year, with this application seeking confirmation for extended temporary period.

haz-substances.hazardous-sub-consent-details: Multiple hazardous substances consent applications required for chemical processing facility. Consultation with HSE ongoing regarding storage and handling procedures.
Existing hazardous substances consent HSC/2023/001 covers ammonia storage. New consent application submitted for additional chlorine storage.

hedgerow-removal.removal-reasons: Business expansion - extending existing farm buildings for livestock housing
Agricultural access improvements required for machinery
Utility infrastructure installation for broadband network expansion
Farm modernization - replacing old hedgerow with new mixed native species hedge

data.proposal-description: Single storey rear extension and garage conversion

parking.description: Garage to be converted to living space. Current off-street parking capacity is 2 cars (1 garage, 1 driveway). After conversion: 1 car driveway parking space will remain.

data.additional-information: Heavy machinery operations (generators, compressors) limited to Monday-Friday 08:00-17:00 only. Emergency equipment may operate outside these hours if required.

immunity-from-listing.application-result: Certificate granted on 15th March 2024 under reference COI/2024/001234. The building was found to be immune from listing due to substantial alterations made prior to 1970.

info-support-ldc.interruption-details: Use interrupted twice: 1) June 2012 to September 2012 for major refurbishment including roof replacement and internal alterations. 2) March 2020 to July 2020 due to COVID-19 lockdown restrictions requiring temporary closure of business operations.
info-support-ldc.existing-use-change-details: Original use was vehicle repair garage (B2). In 2014, part of the building was converted to vehicle sales showroom (sui generis). The rear workshop area remained in B2 use while the front 30% became display area for vehicle sales. Additional changes in 2019 included creation of customer waiting area with refreshment facilities.

info-support-ldc.interruption-details: Use was interrupted from January 2018 to March 2018 due to flood damage repairs. The building was unoccupied for 8 weeks while structural repairs and refurbishment were completed. Use resumed immediately after repairs with same commercial activity.

info-support-ldc.existing-use-change-details: Original use was retail shop (A1). In 2016, the ground floor was partially converted to cafe use (A3) while retaining retail sales area. The change involved installation of kitchen facilities and seating area occupying approximately 40% of the floor space. No external alterations were made.

interest-details.permission-not-obtained-details: Owner could not be contacted despite multiple attempts

data.permission-not-obtained-details: The land owner is currently overseas and cannot be contacted. Attempts have been made through their registered address and known representatives, but no response has been received. The advertisement is for a temporary community event notice that will benefit the local area.

nm-amendment-details.description: Comprehensive revision of development details including updated floor plans, revised elevations, new landscaping scheme, and updated drainage strategy. The amendments address technical requirements identified during detailed design development and consultation feedback.
nm-amendment-details.reason: To incorporate detailed technical requirements identified during design development, address feedback from statutory consultees, and improve the overall quality and sustainability of the development proposal.

nm-amendment-details.description: Amendment to revise external materials specification. The proposed development will now use brick facing rather than render on the front elevation to better harmonise with the existing streetscape and address concerns raised by the conservation officer.
nm-amendment-details.reason: To address conservation concerns and improve the visual integration of the development with the existing streetscape character following feedback from the conservation officer.

nm-amendment-details.description: Minor textual correction to address details in application forms.
nm-amendment-details.reason: Correct typographical error in property address.

nm-amendment-details.description: Amendment to relocate air conditioning unit. The external condensing unit will be moved from the rear elevation to the side elevation to improve visual amenity and reduce noise impact on neighbouring properties.
nm-amendment-details.reason: To improve the visual appearance of the development and reduce noise impact on adjacent residential properties following concerns raised by neighbours during the consultation period.

nm-amendment-details.description: Minor amendment to window specifications. Change from timber casement windows to UPVC windows in white to match existing windows on the property and reduce maintenance requirements.
nm-amendment-details.reason: To match existing fenestration on the property and reduce long-term maintenance costs for the homeowner while maintaining the same visual appearance.

processes-machinery-waste.site-activity-details: Waste management facility for recycling construction materials. Operations include sorting machinery, crushing equipment, and screening systems. Dust suppression systems and containment areas for different material types.

Hazardous waste treatment facility with specialized containment systems. Operations include chemical treatment processes, secure storage areas, and specialized ventilation systems for hazardous materials handling.
Multi-purpose waste management facility including transfer station and material recovery operations. Equipment includes conveyor systems, sorting machinery, baling equipment, and loading facilities.

Industrial facility for manufacturing plastic components. Operations include injection molding machines, cooling systems, and packaging equipment. Ventilation systems include dust extraction and air filtration units.

Outline application for waste management facility. Site will include processing equipment, storage areas, and administrative buildings. Specific machinery and processes to be determined at detailed design stage.

data.storage-facilities-description: Chemical storage facility comprising 3 x 25,000 litre tanks for drilling mud additives and completion fluids. Tanks will be constructed from corrosion-resistant materials with secondary containment systems. The facility includes a dedicated chemical handling area with impermeable flooring, drainage to sealed holding tanks, and automated monitoring systems. Staff welfare facilities include emergency eyewash stations and chemical shower facilities. All storage complies with COSHH regulations and relevant environmental permits.

Comprehensive storage facility for oil and gas operations including: (1) Crude oil storage - 2 x 100,000 barrel insulated tanks with floating roof design, vapor recovery system, and fire suppression; (2) Diesel fuel storage - 75,000 litre double-wall tank with automatic leak detection; (3) Chemical storage - segregated storage areas for acids, bases, and solvents with appropriate compatibility groupings; (4) Gas storage - compressed natural gas cylinders in secure, ventilated housing. All facilities include 24/7 monitoring, emergency response equipment, and are designed to exceed current environmental protection standards.

The proposed development includes a 50,000 litre diesel fuel storage tank constructed with double-wall containment system. The tank will be located in a purpose-built concrete bunded area with 110% capacity containment. All pipework will be above ground with leak detection systems. Emergency shut-off valves will be installed at strategic locations. The facility will comply with Control of Pollution (Oil Storage) (England) Regulations 2001.

replacement-drawings.reason: Updated to include additional fire exit requirements
Revised boundary line to reflect updated survey

trade-effluent.description: The proposed development involves disposal of industrial wastewater at a rate of 500 cubic meters per day through connection to the municipal treatment facility. Effluent will be pre-treated on-site to meet discharge standards before disposal.

tree-work-details.description: Crown reduction of mature oak tree (T1) by 25% to reduce weight on extended limbs and improve structural stability. Selective pruning of silver birch (T2) to remove dead and crossing branches. All work to be carried out in accordance with British Standard BS 3998:2010.

tree-details.description-of-works: Crown reduction by 25% to reduce weight on extended limbs over neighbouring property. Remove dead wood and improve structural integrity.
Selective pruning to remove dead, diseased and crossing branches. Crown lift to 3m above ground level.

tree-work-details.description: Removal of small self-seeded sycamore tree growing against boundary fence. Tree is approximately 4m in height and causing damage to fencing.

tree-details.description-of-works: Complete removal of tree including stump grinding to below ground level.

tree-work-details.description: Pollarding of mature lime tree (TPO/2023/001/T3) to reduce height from 12m to 6m due to structural concerns and subsidence damage to nearby property. Tree to be reduced to previous pollard points. Replanting of two native tree species to be carried out as compensatory planting.

tree-details.description-of-works: Pollard to 6m height, cutting back to previous pollard points. Remove all growth above 6m in height. Clean cuts to be made with sharp tools.
tree-details.reason: Tree showing signs of structural weakness with large limbs over neighbouring property. Root system causing subsidence damage to adjacent building foundation.
tree-details.replanting-description: Two native tree species (Acer campestre and Betula pendula) to be planted in alternative locations within the same curtilage, minimum 3m from buildings. Trees to be minimum 12-14cm girth, supplied with tree guards and irrigation system.

trees-additional.advice-from-authority: LPA officer advised that the oak tree appears healthy but recommend an arboricultural assessment due to its proximity to the listed building.

trees-additional.advice-from-authority: Tree officer visited site on 15/06/2025 and confirmed that the mature oak (T1) is showing signs of decay in the main stem. Recommended immediate arboricultural assessment and consideration of pollarding rather than complete removal to preserve wildlife habitat.

vol-agreement.agreement-summary: Voluntary agreement outlines environmental monitoring requirements and restoration obligations for the extraction site, including quarterly reporting and a 5-year restoration timeline.
